results.title: Drifting Clouds = Kauas pilvet karkaavat
results.brief_description: Lauri drives a tram and Ilona works as a hostess in a grand old hotel. Their life together in Helsinki seems peaceful until Lauri loses his job because the tram company is downsizing and Ilona is retrenched when the hotel she works for closes down. To make matters worse, Lauri has just purchased a brand new television on credit. Ilona takes a job in a greasy-spoon with questionable proprietors and Lauri, after selling the television and the car, indulges in a drinking binge which temporarily isolates him from his wife and home. Upon their reunion, life takes a positive turn when Ilona, with help from her old colleagues from the hotel, decides to open a restaurant, the Worker’s Rest cafe. “Drifting Clouds” is a quiet film enriched by the customary deadpan humour the Kaurismaki brothers are renowned for. Solemn, understated and rich with compassion, the characters are endearing for the genuine concern they show each other. Since the 1980’s the Kaurismaki brothers have produced their own style of absurdist comedy, tempered by a gentleness and minimalism which in “Drifting Clouds”, offsets the grim reality of themes like unemployment and poverty. Timo Salminen’s subtle photography and the strong use of primary colours in the set design create a film memorable for its fine detail and its pathos. Cast includes Kati Outinen and Kari Vaananen. In Finnish with English subtitles.

results.title: Drifting
results.brief_description: Looks at the British herring-fishing, ports drift-fishers in port, and leaving for the fishing grounds. Shows in detail the process of catching the herring.

results.title: Drifters
results.creator_credit: John Grierson and Empire Marketing Board
results.brief_description: The only film ever directed personally by John Grierson. A documentary made for the Empire Marketing Board about the men of the British herring fleets. ‘Drifters’ brought to the screen the labour of the North Sea herring fleet in such a way that the ordinary man or woman was made to realise, perhaps for the first time, that the herring on his plate was no mere accident, but the result of the labour and courage of other men.

results.title: Drifters
results.brief_description: The only film ever directed personally by John Grierson, this documentary was made for the Empire Marketing Board about the men on the British herring fleets, which employed montage and documentary techniques to demonstrate the human side of the fishing industry.

constellations_primary.name: Reconstructing reality
constellations_primary.description: While documentary pertains to be about the truth, many filmmakers and artists have used ingenious reconstructions to represent an abstracted honesty.

results.title: Drift
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and black and white, silent
results.brief_description: Since the first Apollo moon landing in the 1960s, NASA has compiled an enormous photographic record of its lunar saga. San Francisco photographer Michael Light gained access to the original negatives, presenting his collection of photography in major American and European museums including San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. As a reprise to his photographic exhibition ‘Full Moon’, Light has created ‘Drift’, an epic seven-minute loop of composite still imagery taken during NASA’s moon missions.

results.title: Dressing up in the past
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, David Ferris and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Presents Lorri Baines, National Gallery Education Officer, demonstrating what the gallery offers children in terms of the history of clothing and costume. Using two children as models she shows how eighteen century aristocrats would have dressed and the restrictions imposed by their mode of dress.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeff Spencer, David Ferris and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development

results.title: Dressing Dad
results.creator_credit: Sofya Gollan, Isabel Perez and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A short student film in which the filmmaker explores how the relationship with her father was transformed by the knowledge of his being a cross-dresser. Featuring interviews with her father and his transvestite friends, this work dispels many of the common preconceptions about cross-dressing and transvestitism while also being an engaging study of how families cope with aspects of individual difference and gender exploration.

results.title: Dressing dad
results.creator_credit: Lynne Vincent McCarthy, Isabel Perez, Sofya Gollan and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
If your dad wore a dress, would it make him less of a father, less of a man? A daughter’s journey to understand her father’s long-kept secret as a cross-dresser.
Cast: Alastair Barns (the dad), Lynne Vincent McCarthy as the daughter voice-over, and Leslie, Bianca, Kimberley, Steffie and Kim.

results.title: Dressing a Chicken
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description:
Please be advised, this film features footage of dead animals.

Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, this short instructional film demonstrates the correct method for cleaning and dressing poultry. The film is an interesting historical insight into the changing nature of food production and distribution. It would once have been normal for people to handle a fresh chicken carcass rather than a pre-prepared one from the butcher, and the size of the chicken is considerably smaller than today’s standards.

results.title: Dressed to kill
results.creator_credit: Roy William Neill and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Adapted from a story by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and featuring the inimitable Sherlock Holmes (Basil Rathbone) and his sidekick, Dr Watson (Nigel Bruce). In this tale of mystery and suspense, Holmes has to find the whereabouts of three wooden music boxes containing Bank of England engraving plates in order to prevent certain crims out there from basically obtaining a licence to print money. Cast includes Patricia Morison, Edmond Breon, Frederick Worlock, Carl Harbord, Patricia Cameron.
